data.title: Women authors who have won the Nobel Prize in Literature
data.meta_description: Started in 1901, the Nobel Prizes in Literature have been awarded to 117 individuals from 1901-2020 out of which only 16 women authors have won the prize.
data.text:
Nobel Prize in Literature

The Nobel Prize in Literature is one of the most prestigious awards in the literary world. Started in 1901, the Nobel Prizes in Literature have been awarded to 117 individuals from 1901-2020 out of which only 16 women authors have won the prize, according to Nobelprize.org. They are:

Annie Ernaux

French writer Annie Ernaux was announced as the winner of the 2022 Nobel Prize in Literature on October 6, 2022. She is the 17th woman author to win the Nobel Prize in Literature since 1901. Annie Ernaux won the Nobel Prize “for the courage and clinical acuity with which she uncovers the roots, estrangements and collective restraints of personal memory”.

Olga Tokarczuk

Olga Tokarczuk won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2018 “for a narrative imagination that with encyclopedic passion represents the crossing of boundaries as a form of life”.

Svetlana Alexievich

Svetlana Alexievich won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2015 “for her polyphonic writings, a monument to suffering and courage in our time”.

Alice Munro

Alice Munro won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2013 for “master of the contemporary short story”.

Herta Müller

Herta Müller won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2009. Miller "with the concentration of poetry and the frankness of prose, depicts the landscape of the dispossessed”.

Doris Lessing

Doris Lessing won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2007. Lessing's writing is said to have “epicist of the female experience, who with scepticism, fire and visionary power has subjected a divided civilisation to scrutiny”.

Elfriede Jelinek

Elfriede Jelinek won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2004 “for her musical flow of voices and counter-voices in novels and plays that with extraordinary linguistic zeal reveal the absurdity of society’s clichés and their subjugating power”.

Wislawa Szymborska

Wislawa Szymborska won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1996 “for poetry that with ironic precision allows the historical and biological context to come to light in fragments of human reality”.

Toni Morrison

Toni Morrison won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1993. Morrison "in novels characterized by visionary force and poetic import, gives life to an essential aspect of American reality," according to the Nobelprize.org.

Nadine Gordimer

Nadine Gordimer won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1991. Gordimer “through her magnificent epic writing has – in the words of Alfred Nobel – been of very great benefit to humanity,” according to the Nobelprize.org.

Nelly Sachs

Nelly Sachs won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1966 “for her outstanding lyrical and dramatic writing, which interprets Israel’s destiny with touching strength”.

Gabriela Mistral

Gabriela Mistral won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1945 “for her lyric poetry which, inspired by powerful emotions, has made her name a symbol of the idealistic aspirations of the entire Latin American world”.

Pearl Buck

Pearl Buck won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1938 “for her rich and truly epic descriptions of peasant life in China and for her biographical masterpieces”.
